title: Vase, ca. 1910
provenance: 2013, Given to Cooper-Hewitt by owner Harry C. Sigman
description: Hammered cylindrical vase gently narrowing at the top with a simple decoration of German silver in a Native American pattern, a double band encircling the vase with a dropping design at four points.
justification:
Roycroft began in 1897 with Elbert Hubbard, in East Aurora NY. It was more than a manufactory; it&nbsp;was a&nbsp;way of life devoted to the&nbsp;arts and crafts. For more than 20 years, the Roycroft Campus was a hub of activity with over five hundred working artisans and craftsmen and drew visitors from long distances.&nbsp; The objects produced reflected the hand-crafted look of the arts and crafts movement but aimed to make the objects accessible financially, partly through a choice of materials. This copper vase has&nbsp;an overlay of&nbsp;a silver alloy sometimes known as German silver, co-ordinated with the interiors created there. While copper objects started being produced in 1902,&nbsp;around 1910 Dard Hunter&nbsp;and&nbsp;Karl Kipp,&nbsp;the two principal designers,&nbsp;collaborated on some Roycroft copper designs, and an&nbsp;early Vienna Secession-influenced&nbsp;&nbsp;style starts to emerge with geometric designs, cut-outs and "German&nbsp;silver" overlays. This vase seems to fall into that category and&nbsp;is therefore likely to be of similar date.
An example of a hammered copper jardiniere with German silver trimmings, designed by Karl Kipp, ca. 1910-11, is in the permanent collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.

tombstone.epitaph: Vase, ca. 1910. Hand-hammered copper, "German silver" (white metal alloy). Gift of Harry C. Sigman. 2013-21-41.
